questions.text: The peripheral blood smear of a patient is given below. All of the following can cause this except:
questions.solution:
The given image shows hypersegmented neutrophils (> 5 nuclear lobes), which are seen in megaloblastic anemia. Chronic alcoholism causes non-megaloblastic macrocytic anemia.

Megaloblastic anemia is a form of macrocytic anemia with impaired nucleic acid metabolism and defective erythropoiesis. The causes include vitamin B12 deficiency, folate deficiency, and orotic aciduria. Nuclear maturation lags behind cytoplasmic maturation giving the appearance of hypersegmented neutrophils. Peripheral smear findings include: 

  • Oval macrocytes
  • Anisocytosis
  • Hypersegmented neutrophils 

Other features of ineffective erythropoiesis seen in megaloblastic anemias include:

  • Howell-Jolly bodies are nuclear remnants in red cells. They are usually single, round, dark purple-red in color and peripheral in location, as shown below.                                            
  • Basophilic stippling refers to blue granules of various sizes dispersed throughout the cytoplasm of the red cell. They represent ribosomal precipitates.
  • Cabot rings are red cell inclusions appearing as fine, purple filamentous loops or figure-of-eight forms, as shown below. They are presumed to be remnants of mitotic spindles.

questions.text: Patients with which of the following conditions are unlikely to develop cobalamin deficiency?
questions.solution:
Ancylostoma duodenale (hookworm) infection does not affect the absorption of cobalamin or vitamin B12. Small amounts of blood loss during the attachment of hookworms to the intestinal mucosa can cause iron-deficiency anemia.

Vitamin B12-intrinsic factor (IF) complex is absorbed in the ileum. Tropical sprue, Diphyllobothrium latum (fish tapeworm) infection and Crohn's disease affect the ileum leading to defective absorption of vitamin B12.

Related Pearl: Causes of Megaloblastic Anemia

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Vegetarianism
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Intrinsic factor deficiency
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Gastrectomy
    • Malabsorption states
    • Diffuse intestinal disease (e.g., lymphoma, systemic sclerosis)
    • Ileal resection
    • Ileitis
  • Competitive parasitic uptake
    • Fish tapeworm infestation
    • Bacterial overgrowth in blind loops and diverticula of bowel

  • Increased Loss

  • Increased Requirement

    • Markedly increased hematopoiesis
  • Impaired Utilization
    • Folic acid antagonists
    • Unresponsive to vitamin B12 or folic acid therapy

questions.text: Which of the following would not be seen in a patient with cyanocobalamin deficiency?
questions.solution:
Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia is seen in cyanocobalamin or vitamin B12 deficiency, not conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

Vitamin B12 deficiency causes megaloblastic anemia due to ineffective erythropoiesis. This leads to the formation of nucleated RBCs in the marrow, which undergo early lysis. This leads to increased unconjugated bilirubin in the plasma.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old male patient is being evaluated for peripheral neuropathy and excessive tiredness. He has uncontrolled diabetes and consumes alcohol nearly every day. Lab investigations reveal the following findings. What is the likely diagnosis?

Hemoglobin - 9g/dl

Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) - 112 fL

Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC) = 34 g/dl

Serum homocysteine - Elevated

Serum methyl malonic acid - Normal
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of folate deficiency.

It is associated with the following clinical and laboratory findings:

  • Raised MCV (normal: 80-100 fL) - macrocytosis
  • Normal MCHC (normal: 33-36 g/dl) 
  • Increased MCH (mean corpuscular hemoglobin)
  • Elevated RDW (red cell distribution width)
  • Decreased reticulocyte count - due to destruction of abnormal erythroid precursors
  • Elevated homocysteine
  • Normal MMA (methyl malonic acid)

In vitamin B12 deficiency, elevated homocysteine and elevated MMA levels are seen. 

Peripheral neuropathy is a feature of B12 deficiency, not folate deficiency. In this patient, it may be due to diabetic neuropathy.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not associated with megaloblastic anemia?
questions.solution:
Temafloxacin is not associated with megaloblastic anemia.

Megaloblastic anemia is associated with the following drugs:

  • Anticonvulsant drugs - phenytoin, primidone, barbiturates
  • Sulfasalazine
  • Nitrofurantoin
  • Tetracycline
  • Folate antagonists - trimethoprim, methotrexate, pyrimethamine, pentamidine, cotrimoxazole

Temafloxacin is a fluoroquinolone with severe adverse effects like hemolytic anemia and allergic reactions. It was withdrawn from the market and is no longer used.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman is rushed to the ER following a seizure. She is a known case of epilepsy but is non-compliant with her medications. Her lab values are given below. All of the following drugs can cause this presentation except:

Hemoglobin - 10g/dl

MCV - 110 fL

MCH - 40 pg

MCHC - 34 g/dl
questions.solution:
This patient likely has folate deficiency secondary to the use of an anti-folate anti-convulsant drug. Lamotrigine has no effect on folate metabolism and does not cause its deficiency.

The following anticonvulsants have anti-folate properties: 

  • Phenytoin
  • Barbiturates (amobarbital)
  • Primidone 

Folate deficiency causes megaloblastic macrocytic anemia which results in the following findings in RBCs:

  • Anemia (low Hb = 10g/dl)
  • Macrocytic (high MCV = 110 fl)
  • Hyperchromic (high MCH = 40 pg)

questions.text: A dose of oral 58-Co-labeled cobalamin was administered to a 65-year-old woman. The 24-hour urinary excretion of radiolabeled cobalamin was found to be < 10%. The test was repeated after a 5-day course of antibiotics and showed urinary excretion > 10%. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario refers to Schilling's test done for the determination of the cause of B12 deficiency. Improvement of urinary B12 excretion > 10% after antibiotic administration is suggestive of small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO).

Related Pearl: Schilling Test

The Schilling test is done to determine the cause of vitamin B12 deficiency. It involves the administration of radiolabeled vitamin B12 followed by the 24-hour collection of urine. The test is then repeated with an additional component that can promote vitamin B12 absorption. If the additional component is able to correct the defect and radiolabeled vitamin B12 is absorbed, it will be detected in the urine.

questions.text: A child diagnosed with megaloblastic anemia failed to respond to treatment with vitamin C, vitamin B12, and folic acid. He was started on uridine monophosphate which improved his symptoms. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Megaloblastic anemia that is responsive to treatment with uridine is suggestive of orotic aciduria.

Orotic aciduria is a rare inborn error of metabolism in children. It occurs due to a defect in the pyrimidine synthesis pathway causing a failure of conversion of orotic acid to uridine. It manifests in early childhood with anemia and failure to thrive.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with fatigue and a red, painful tongue. On examination, there is reduced vibration sense and proprioception in the feet. She is under treatment for Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Peripheral smear reveals macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils. Which of the following is unlikely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario in a patient with a history of autoimmune thyroiditis is suspicious for pernicious anemia. It is an autoimmune cause of B12 deficiency. Antibodies against gastrin are not seen in these patients. The following autoantibodies are seen: 

  • Type I or blocking antibodies - prevent the combination of IF and cobalamin
  • Type II or binding antibodies - prevent attachment of IF to the ileal mucosa
  • Anti-parietal cell antibodies - target the gastric proton pump located in these cells

This leads to the deficiency of the intrinsic factor of Castle (IF) and hydrochloric acid produced by the parietal cells. The resulting atrophic gastritis causes high gastrin and low pepsinogen levels. Lack of IF further causes vitamin B12 deficiency and megaloblastic anemia.

questions.text: A pathologist receives a gastric biopsy sample of a patient with pernicious anemia. Which of the following findings is he unlikely to find?
questions.solution:
Gastric biopsy in pernicious anemia shows loss of glandular elements, not hypertrophy. 

This is an autoimmune condition that occurs in genetically susceptible individuals. One of the common triggers of the disease process is Helicobacter pylori infection. Gastric biopsy findings in pernicious anemia include the following:

  • Atrophy of all layers of the body and fundus
    • Loss of glandular elements
    • Absence of parietal and chief cells and replacement by mucus cells
    • Mixed inflammatory cell infiltrate (excess of CD4 cells against gastric H+/K+-ATPase)
    • Intestinal metaplasia
  • Antral mucosa is usually well preserved.

questions.text: Patients with pernicious anemia are at a higher risk of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Patients with pernicious anemia have an increased risk of intestinal-type of gastric adenocarcinoma and gastric carcinoid tumors. These patients must undergo regular endoscopic screening for these conditions.

The presumed mechanism is prolonged achlorhydria due to parietal cell loss. This leads to hypergastrinemia and cellular hyperplasia.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of folate deficiency?
questions.solution:
Reduced nutritional intake is the most common cause of folate deficiency.

questions.text: Dietary folates are absorbed from which of the following sites?
questions.solution:
Dietary folates are absorbed from the duodenum and jejunum in the form of monoglutamates. 

Vitamin B12 absorption takes place in the terminal ileum.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman is brought with increased forgetfulness and clumsiness for the past 1 month. Since the death of her husband 3 months ago, she has been tired and eating poorly. She began taking over-the-counter iron and folic acid tablets 2 months ago. Examination reveals positive Romberg's sign with eyes closed and loss of vibration in lower extremities. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of dorsal column involvement of the spinal cord due to underlying vitamin B12 deficiency.

Vitamin B12 deficiency causes subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord (SACD). It affects the following structures: 

  • Dorsal column - sensory loss, paresthesias, incontinence, sensory ataxia (positive Romberg sign with eyes closed)
  • Lateral column - spasticity and paraplegias in later stages

Folate deficiency is typically not associated with neurological manifestations. In patients with combined deficiency of B12 and folate, B12 deficiency must always be corrected first. This is because the administration of folate supplements may improve hematologic abnormalities but worsens neurological manifestations. 

Treatment of cobalamin deficiency is as follows:

  • Replenishment of body stores: Six 1000-μg IM injections of hydroxocobalamin given at 3- to 7-day intervals.
  • Maintenance therapy: 1000 μg hydroxocobalamin IM once every 3 months 

Treatment of folate deficiency is as follows:

  • 5–15 mg oral folic acid daily for a minimum of 4 months.

Option C: Thiamine deficiency causes Wernicke's syndrome with ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and nystagmus. As this is due to cerebellar damage, Romberg's sign would be positive even with eyes open.

Option D: Pyridoxine deficiency causes pellagra like syndrome with features of dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia.

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl with a seizure disorder is started on phenytoin therapy. Which of the following must be supplemented in this patient?
questions.solution:
Usage of phenytoin leads to folate deficiency and megaloblastic anemia. Hence, folic acid must be supplemented.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to you for pre-conceptional counseling. Her previous pregnancy resulted in fetal death due to a neural tube defect. What dose of folic acid would you recommend?

choices.text: 400 μg  pre-conceptionally and in first trimester
4-5 mg pre-conceptionally and in first trimester

questions.solution:
The recommended prophylactic dose of folic acid in women who have had a previous fetus with a neural tube defect is 4-5 mg daily, pre-conceptionally, and during the first trimester of pregnancy. Following the first trimester, these patients are then switched to 400 μg of folic acid for the remainder of the pregnancy.

This high dose of folic acid (4-5 mg) should be initiated at least one to three months before pregnancy and should be continued for 12 weeks after pregnancy. The patient can be prescribed 1 mg tablet of folic acid and advised to take them 4- 5 times a day or they can be recommended 5mg tablets/capsules once daily.

Prophylactic folic acid with 400 μg daily, pre-conceptionally, and throughout pregnancy is indicated in all pregnant women to prevent megaloblastic anemia and reduce the incidence of neural tube defects.

questions.text: Which of the following would not be seen in a patient with Imerslund-Grasbeck syndrome?
questions.solution:
Imerslund-Grasbeck syndrome (IGS) is an autosomal recessive disorder.

IGS occurs due to mutations in either the cubulin (CUBN) or amnionless (AMN) genes. They form the cubam receptor responsible for the absorption of the Cbl-IF complex. Hence, this condition leads to congenital cobalamin malabsorption. It is the most common cause of megaloblastic anemia due to B12 deficiency in infancy in Western countries.

Affected children present with lethargy, failure to thrive, and neurological symptoms like hypotonia, developmental delay, and movement disorders. Non-specific proteinuria with normal renal function is seen in 90% of patients.
